Dispute_Type: Alleged discriminatory funding practices by INAC against larger First Nations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission's decision to investigate a complaint of discrimination based on national or ethnic origin is reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision to investigate was reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: Not plain and obvious that the complaint fell outside jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5(b) prohibits adverse differentiation based on prohibited grounds including national or ethnic origin; Section 41(1)(c) allows dismissal of complaints outside jurisdiction
Procedural_Issue: Commission's authority to investigate under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Funding formulas disadvantage larger First Nations due to size, alleged as discrimination based on national or ethnic origin
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Commission's decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of funding formulas and their impact on larger First Nations
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, sections 5(b) and 41(1)(c); Federal Courts Act, section 18.1
Applicant_Challenge: Size is not a prohibited ground; no link between funding and national origin
Defendant_Response: Funding formulas do not constitute discrimination based on national or ethnic origin
Legal_Provision: Section 5(b), Section 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Complaint potentially outside jurisdiction due to lack of link to prohibited grounds
Jurisdiction: Canadian Human Rights Commission jurisdiction over matters of federal jurisdiction involving prohibited grounds of discrimination
Governing_Rule: Section 5(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
